author: Staff Reporter
text:
Inspired by Harish who donated organs after being severed by truck

The State government is set to launch a cashless treatment plan for road accident victims in memory of 23-year-old Harish Nanjappa. To be named Mukhyamantrigala Santwana Harish scheme, it entitles accident victims to immediate cashless treatment at hospitals for up to 48 hours with a cap of Rs. 25,000. It will be launched on Monday.

Harish was severed after coming under the wheel of a truck.

While lying on the road waiting for assistance, he pledged to donate his eyes and other organs. This gesture inspired several hundred people in his village to donate organs.

The scheme will look at providing assistance to victims of road traffic accidents across the State irrespective of their financial status or nationality.

The victim will receive medical care for 48 hours and will be able to receive treatment from a set of 25 treatment and ancillary packages, which were recommended for accident victims by an expert committee.

In order to ensure proper implementation, it will employ a software covering hospital registration, patient registration, claims submission and packages. Participating hospitals have been categorised into Level 1, 2 and 3 trauma centres based on the facilities available with Level 3 hospitals being accorded the status of major trauma centres.

The packages covered under this scheme include treatment for simple injury, complicated facial injury, injury of extremities, fractures, head injuries, blood transfusion and burn related injuries among others.

Under existing schemes, poly-trauma cases covered include only non-medico-legal cases, which contribute only 1 per cent of the total cases.

More information on the scheme can be obtained by calling 108 or 104.

Highlights

Cashless treatment for

48 hours after mishap

Cap of Rs. 25,000

25 treatment packages

Injuries covered

Complicated facial injury

Injury of extremities

Fractures

Head injuries

Burns
title: Cashless treatment plan for road accident victims
